channel.title: Reviews on I Prefer Jim
channel.description: Recent content in Reviews on I Prefer Jim

item.title: Finding Wakelocks in Android 7 using Google’s Battery Historian
item.description: One of my favorite apps prior to my upgrade to Android 7 (Nougat) was GSam Battery Monitor (the paid version is fully worth it).

item.title: Review: Core Java for the Impatient
item.description: I’ve just finished reading Core Java for the Impatient by Cay S. Horstmann. I also own Scala for the Impatient by the same author, and I really loved that book.

item.title: Review “Learning 2D Game Development with Unity: A Hands-On Guide to Game Creation”
item.description: I’ve just finished reading Learning 2D Game Development with Unity: A Hands-On Guide to Game Creation, and I really enjoyed it despite many issues with the actual text (I’ll try to cover everything here).

item.title: Review: Swift for the Really Impatient
item.description: I’ve recently finished reading Swift for the Really Impatient. It was a really good book; I’d give it 4 out of 5 stars.

item.title: Review: Microsoft .NET – Architecting Applications for the Enterprise, 2nd Edition
item.description: I’ve recently finished reading Microsoft .NET – Architecting Applications for the Enterprise, 2nd Edition by Dino Esposito and Andrea Saltarello. This book caught my attention for two reasons.

item.title: NDepend is unbelievably rich in features
item.description: I’ve recently begun evaluating NDepend 5.4.1. During the installation process, I’ll admit I was a little underwhelmed. After the Visual Studio plugin loaded, I became overwhelmed. After digging into the many features, I don’t know how or why teams operate without such tools. Let me explain…

item.title: Review: From Mathematics to Generic Programming
item.description: From Mathematics to Generic Programming (Product Page)   (This is a repost of my Amazon review) I’ve been out of college for a while.

item.title: Software Abstractions take Skill.
item.description: I recently read Adaptive Code via C# and posted a review on Amazon: This book is a new favorite of mine.

item.title: Functional Thinking is… functional
item.description: Product: Functional Thinking by O’Reilly Digital Media Submitted at: O’Reilly Pros: <div> Concise, Easy to understand, Accurate, Helpful examples </div> <div> </div> Best Uses: <div> Intermediate, Expert, Novice, Student </div> <div> </div> Describe Yourself: <div> Developer </div> <div> </div> I’ve reviewed Neal Ford’s “Functional Thinking” video series as part of O’Reilly’s bloggers program and I must say it is one of the best videos I’ve seen.

item.title: My review of Python Cookbook, 3rd Edition by O’Reilly Digital Media
item.description: Product: Python Cookbook, 3rd Edition by O’Reilly Digital Media Submitted at: O’Reilly Fantastic Cookbook by JimSchubert from Seattle WA on 7/27/2013

item.description: Computer Science Programming Basics In Ruby Originally submitted at O’Reilly Product: Computer Science Programming Basics in Ruby by oreilly Submitted at: O’Reilly Great intro to basics!

item.title: jQuery Pocket Reference by David Flanagan
item.description: jQuery Pocket Reference by David Flanagan I’ve enjoyed previous books by David Flanagan and decided to read jQuery Pocket Reference. I thought I would quickly skim through the chapters because I considered myself fairly proficient in jQuery.
